paramId0002.content:
Congratulations on your new job! Working in a recording studio is really cool.

I’m Larry. We will be working together, and I have been asked to train you.

I will guide you through some of the tasks required for our job.

paramId0009.content: At a tempo of 60 beats per minute, there is one beat every At a tempo of 120 beats per minute, there is one beat every So a tempo of 60 beats per minute is as fast as a tempo of 120 beats per minute.

paramId0010.content: Playing a piece of music at a tempo of 120 beats per minute takes as long as playing the same piece of music at a tempo of 60 beats per minute.

paramId0011.content: A piece of music with 300 beats played at 120 beats per minute takes minutes to play. The same piece of music played at 60 beats per minutes takes  minutes to play.

paramId0013.content: A tempo of 80 beats per minute corresponds to second(s) per beat.

paramId0014.content: When comparing two different tempos, the tempo with a greater number of beats per minute is the tempo, and the tempo with a greater number of seconds per beat is the tempo.

paramId0024.content:
How many measures are played in the video?

 measures

paramId0026.content:
Drum Tempo

How many beats per minute is the drum playing?

paramId0033.content:
Piano Tempo

What is the tempo, in beats per minute, of the piano?

beats per minute

paramId0036.content: Theis playing at a faster tempo.

paramId0037.content:
• The drum is playing at a rate of 1 beat every second(s).
  • The piano is playing at a rate of 1 beat every second(s).

paramId0039.content: At these tempos, how many more beats will the piano play than the drum in 30 seconds?

paramId0046.content:
Guitar Tempo

The tempo of the guitar is the tempo of the drum because it plays beats in time.

paramId0047.content:
Verify the comparison of the two tempos by completing the following table.

Give your answers to the nearest tenth of a second.

Number of BeatsTime (in seconds)
GuitarDrum
4
16
2419.216

paramId0066.content:
You did an awesome job today! You learned this part of the job very quickly.

There is so much more to learn in this industry, but you are off to a great start!

paramId0069.content: So each beat in a tempo of 120 beats per minute lasts.

paramId1009.content:
When music is recorded in a studio, sometimes the instruments are recorded separately. They are then mixed together with software so that each sound is perfectly balanced, outside noise is eliminated, and effects can be added.

Listen to these three instruments played separately.

paramId1058.content:
When these three recordings are all mixed together, it doesn't sound right. Listen for yourself.

The problem with the music you just heard is that each instrument is playing at a different speed.

paramId1065.content: The problem with the music you just heard is that each instrument is playing at a different speed.

paramId1086.content:
Let’s start with a quick music lesson.

  • The speed of music is called tempo.
  • Tempo can be measured in beats per minute.

Remember, there are 60 seconds in one minute.

Complete the sentences to compare two tempos.

paramId1127.content:
Some composers do not calculate the tempo in beats per minute. Instead, they calculate the number of seconds per beat.

Complete the sentence to compare the methods used to calculate tempos.

paramId1149.content:
Now let’s practice.

You know how sometimes, when you are listening to music, you clap your hands? That’s because you are listening to the beat. With the aid of video, we can also SEE the beat.

Watch this video. It is a wave representation of the drum sound that we heard earlier.

Each beat shows up in the video as a peak.

paramId1170.content:
It may help to see the tempo on a line with tick marks at every beat.

Play the video again, and notice that each beat matches a tick mark on the line.

paramId1191.content:
Since there are so many beats, it may be easier to count by measures.

Each measure in this piece of music is made up of 4  beats.

I marked the first beat of the first measure on the line. Count all the measures by selecting the first beat of each measure on the line.

paramId1212.content: In 16 seconds, the drum plays 6 measures, which corresponds to 24 beats.

paramId1222.content: In 16 seconds, the drum actually plays 6 measures, which corresponds to 24 beats.

paramId1229.content:
By listening to the music again, you might hear that the tempos of all three instruments are different.

We need to adjust the beats per minute of the other instruments so that their tempos match that of the drum.

paramId1250.content:
This video is the wave representation of the sound of the piano.

Listen carefully, and see if you can hear the 4 beats in each measure.

paramId1309.content:
That’s right.

  • The drum plays 90 beats per minute.
  • The piano plays 100 beats per minute.

paramId1319.content:
Here are the correct tempos.

  • The drum plays 90 beats per minute.
  • The piano plays 100 beats per minute.

paramId1326.content:
Now, let’s listen to the guitar.

Hearing the tempo of this guitar piece is more difficult, but don’t worry. I will help you out.

paramId1365.content:
The guitar is playing 24 beats every 19.2 seconds, while the drum is playing 24 beats in 16 seconds.

Complete the sentence to compare the tempos at which the instruments are playing.

paramId1426.content:
Now it makes sense why the mixed version of the three recordings did not sound right. We have to make the tempos match.

Let’s adjust the tempos of the guitar and the piano to match that of the drum.

We will start with the guitar.

Use the slider to choose the factor by which the tempo of the guitar should be multiplied to match the tempo of the drum.

paramId1451.content:
Now let’s do the same with the piano. Adjust its tempo to match that of the drum.

Use the slider to choose the factor by which the tempo of the piano should be multiplied to match the tempo of the drum.

paramId1476.content:
Thanks!

Let’s listen to the three instruments together, now that all the recordings are set at 90 beats per minute.

Now THAT’s music to my ears!

paramId1584.content:
Complete the sentences to compare the tempos, in seconds per beat, at which the instruments are playing.

Remember:

  • The drum plays 90 beats per minute.
  • The piano plays 100 beats per minute.
